JUDGES: András Sajó;Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Kristina Pardalos;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: The applicants , Mr PERSON , Ms E Kaygan and Mr A. Kaygan , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . They were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The second applicant , whose regular check - ups during her pregnancy were carried out by a private hospital , gave birth to the third applicant on DATE . The third applicant was born with serious disabilities .
On DATE the applicants initiated civil proceedings before ORG ( hereinafter “ the GPE court ” ) against the hospital and doctors , claiming pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage .

On DATE the GPE court requested an expert report from ORG as to the liability of the defendant hospital and the doctors . The report was delivered on DATE and found that no negligence was attributable to the defendant party . Subsequently CARDINAL more medical reports , drawn up by various specialist bodies on DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE and DATE , were submitted to the GPE court . It was established in these reports that the hospital and the doctors involved had in fact been partly responsible for the third applicant ’s disabilities , which had been assessed at PERCENT .
On DATE the applicants lodged a second case with the GPE court , requesting additional compensation for non - pecuniary damage .
On DATE the GPE court ordered the CARDINAL cases to be joined and on DATE it awarded the applicants their claim in full for both cases . The defendant party appealed .

On DATE ORG upheld the judgment in respect of the award granted for the first case and quashed in so far as it concerned the second case . Relying on LAW , ORG held that the second case had been introduced out of time since the first and second applicants had been aware of the serious disabilities and their extent when the third applicant was born . Thus , any claim had had to be introduced within DATE of the third applicant ’s date of birth . The case was remitted to the GPE court .

On DATE the GPE court confirmed in its earlier judgment and held that it was only by having regard to the report dated DATE that the third applicant ’s disability had been established at PERCENT . Therefore the ORG further claims had been introduced within the statutory time - limit . The case file was transferred to ORG of ORG ( Hukuk PERSON ) .

On DATE the Grand Chamber of ORG quashed the judgment of the GPE court . In its decision it discussed in detail the concept of damage , when it arose and when the statutory time - limit for claiming damages had started to run for the instant case . It noted in particular that the seriousness of the third applicant ’s disability had been visible at birth on DATE and , according to medical reports , would not change in time for better or worse . Therefore the DATE statutory time - limit for claiming damages ought to have started running at birth .

The applicants appealed . On DATE the Grand Chamber of ORG dismissed the appeal . The case was remitted to the GPE court , which held on DATE that there was no need to issue a new judgment concerning the applicants’ first claim , which had already become final , whereas their second claim had been introduced outside the statutory time - limits , as established by ORG .
The applicants appealed in respect of the costs and fees .
On DATE ORG amended the part of the judgment concerning the applicants’ costs and fees but upheld the merits .
The applicants were notified of the judgment on DATE .
